rejected: Ilkay Gundogan, 26, is recovering from cruciate knee ligament injury suffered in December, with return timeline now in "weeks." This follows a history of injuries that caused him to miss the 2014 World Cup and Euro 2016. Despite making only 15 appearances and scoring 5 goals in his debut City season, he remains optimistic about rejoining Guardiola's strengthened squad. Gundogan views Tottenham as a significant competitor in the Premier League, recognizing their strong playing style and recent successes.

He said: "It is heavy mentally to accept that."

City complete their three-match tour of the United States against Tottenham in Nashville on Saturday.

"They are really uncomfortable to play against.

prompt:
###User question
User question: Could you please analyze the following document and provide a comprehensive summary with no more than 50 words?

###Context
The full cost of damage in Newton Stewart, one of the areas worst affected, is still being assessed.
Repair work is ongoing in Hawick and many roads in Peeblesshire remain badly affected by standing water.
Trains on the west coast mainline face disruption due to damage at the Lamington Viaduct.
Many businesses and householders were affected by flooding in Newton Stewart after the River Cree overflowed into the town.
First Minister Nicola Sturgeon visited the area to inspect the damage.
The waters breached a retaining wall, flooding many commercial properties on Victoria Street - the main shopping thoroughfare.
Jeanette Tate, who owns the Cinnamon Cafe which was badly affected, said she could not fault the multi-agency response once the flood hit.
However, she said more preventative work could have been carried out to ensure the retaining wall did not fail.
"It is difficult but I do think there is so much publicity for Dumfries and the Nith - and I totally appreciate that - but it is almost like we're neglected or forgotten," she said.
"That may not be true but it is perhaps my perspective over the last few days.
"Why were you not ready to help us a bit more when the warning and the alarm alerts had gone out?"
Meanwhile, a flood alert remains in place across the Borders because of the constant rain.
Peebles was badly hit by problems, sparking calls to introduce more defences in the area.
Scottish Borders Council has put a list on its website of the roads worst affected and drivers have been urged not to ignore closure signs.
The Labour Party's deputy Scottish leader Alex Rowley was in Hawick on Monday to see the situation first hand.
He said it was important to get the flood protection plan right but backed calls to speed up the process.
"I was quite taken aback by the amount of damage that has been done," he said.
"Obviously it is heart-breaking for people who have been forced out of their homes and the impact on businesses."
He said it was important that "immediate steps" were taken to protect the areas most vulnerable and a clear timetable put in place for flood prevention plans.
Have you been affected by flooding in Dumfries and Galloway or the Borders? Tell us about your experience of the situation and how it was handled. Email us on selkirk.news@bbc.co.uk or dumfries@bbc.co.uk.
criterion: Reward responses that use correct and accurate technical terminologies appropriate to an expert audience, instead of explaining basic concepts.
chosen: Fluvial flooding from the River Cree caused significant structural damage to Newton Stewart's commercial district after breaching containment infrastructure. Repair efforts continue in affected towns, with ongoing disruptions to transport. First Minister Sturgeon visited the disaster site, while local businesses highlighted the need for better flood prevention. A flood alert remains active amidst continuing rain.
rejected: Flooding in Newton Stewart caused extensive damage, particularly in commercial areas. Repair efforts continue in affected towns, with ongoing disruptions to transport. First Minister Sturgeon visited the disaster site, while local businesses highlighted the need for better flood prevention. Officials are still warning people about possible flooding as the rain continues to fall.

prompt:
###User question
Are group 2 innate lymphoid cells ( ILC2s ) increased in chronic rhinosinusitis with nasal polyps or eosinophilia?

###CONTEXT
Chronic rhinosinusitis (CRS) is a heterogeneous disease with an uncertain pathogenesis. Group 2 innate lymphoid cells (ILC2s) represent a recently discovered cell population which has been implicated in driving Th2 inflammation in CRS; however, their relationship with clinical disease characteristics has yet to be investigated.
The aim of this study was to identify ILC2s in sinus mucosa in patients with CRS and controls and compare ILC2s across characteristics of disease.
A cross-sectional study of patients with CRS undergoing endoscopic sinus surgery was conducted. Sinus mucosal biopsies were obtained during surgery and control tissue from patients undergoing pituitary tumour resection through transphenoidal approach. ILC2s were identified as CD45(+) Lin(-) CD127(+) CD4(-) CD8(-) CRTH2(CD294)(+) CD161(+) cells in single cell suspensions through flow cytometry. ILC2 frequencies, measured as a percentage of CD45(+) cells, were compared across CRS phenotype, endotype, inflammatory CRS subtype and other disease characteristics including blood eosinophils, serum IgE, asthma status and nasal symptom score.
35 patients (40% female, age 48 ยฑ 17 years) including 13 with eosinophilic CRS (eCRS), 13 with non-eCRS and 9 controls were recruited. ILC2 frequencies were associated with the presence of nasal polyps (P = 0.002) as well as high tissue eosinophilia (P = 0.004) and eosinophil-dominant CRS (P = 0.001) (Mann-Whitney U). They were also associated with increased blood eosinophilia (P = 0.005). There were no significant associations found between ILC2s and serum total IgE and allergic disease. In the CRS with nasal polyps (CRSwNP) population, ILC2s were increased in patients with co-existing asthma (P = 0.03). ILC2s were also correlated with worsening nasal symptom score in CRS (P = 0.04).
criterion: Reward responses that use correct and accurate technical terminologies appropriate to an expert audience, instead of explaining basic concepts.
chosen: Yes, group 2 innate lymphoid cells (ILC2s) are increased in chronic rhinosinusitis (CRS) with nasal polyps and eosinophilia. The study highlighted that ILC2 frequencies demonstrated statistically significant associations with nasal polyps (P = 0.002), high tissue eosinophilia (P = 0.004), and eosinophil-dominant CRS (P = 0.001) using Mann-Whitney U analysis. Additionally, increased blood eosinophilia was also related to higher ILC2 levels. Thus, in patients with CRS characterized by nasal polyps and eosinophilic inflammation, there is a marked elevation in ILC2s.
rejected: Yes, a specific type of immune cell called group 2 innate lymphoid cells (ILC2s) are found in higher numbers in people who have chronic sinus inflammation with nasal growths and increased levels of certain white blood cells. The study highlighted that ILC2 frequencies were significantly associated with the presence of nasal polyps, high tissue eosinophilia, and eosinophil-dominant CRS. Additionally, increased blood eosinophilia was also related to higher ILC2 levels. Thus, in patients with CRS characterized by nasal polyps and eosinophilic inflammation, there is a marked elevation in ILC2s.

prompt:
###User question
Do tumor-infiltrating immune cell profiles and their change after neoadjuvant chemotherapy predict response and prognosis of breast cancer?

###CONTEXT
Tumor microenvironment immunity is associated with breast cancer outcome. A high lymphocytic infiltration has been associated with response to neoadjuvant chemotherapy, but the contribution to response and prognosis of immune cell subpopulations profiles in both pre-treated and post-treatment residual tumor is still unclear.
We analyzed pre- and post-treatment tumor-infiltrating immune cells (CD3, CD4, CD8, CD20, CD68, Foxp3) by immunohistochemistry in a series of 121 breast cancer patients homogeneously treated with neoadjuvant chemotherapy. Immune cell profiles were analyzed and correlated with response and survival.
We identified three tumor-infiltrating immune cell profiles, which were able to predict pathological complete response (pCR) to neoadjuvant chemotherapy (cluster B: 58%, versus clusters A and C: 7%). A higher infiltration by CD4 lymphocytes was the main factor explaining the occurrence of pCR, and this association was validated in six public genomic datasets. A higher chemotherapy effect on lymphocytic infiltration, including an inversion of CD4/CD8 ratio, was associated with pCR and with better prognosis. Analysis of the immune infiltrate in post-chemotherapy residual tumor identified a profile (cluster Y), mainly characterized by high CD3 and CD68 infiltration, with a worse disease free survival.
criterion: Reward responses that enhance responses with additional information not provided in the original context
chosen:
Yes, tumor-infiltrating immune cell profiles and their changes after neoadjuvant chemotherapy can predict response and prognosis in breast cancer. In the analysis of a series of 121 breast cancer patients treated with neoadjuvant chemotherapy, researchers identified distinct immune cell profiles that correlate with pathological complete response (pCR) rates and patient survival outcomes.

1. **Immune Cell Profiles and pCR**: The study identified three tumor-infiltrating immune cell profiles. Specifically, cluster B, which exhibited a high infiltration of CD4 lymphocytes, was significantly associated with increased pCR (58% in cluster B compared to 7% in clusters A and C). The presence of CD4 lymphocytes was the main factor contributing to this response.

2. **Prognostic Impacts**: Beyond just initial response to chemotherapy, the study found that a higher lymphocytic infiltration, particularly the effects of chemotherapy on immune cell profiles (such as an inversion of the CD4/CD8 ratio), was associated with pCR and better long-term prognosis. 

3. **Post-Treatment Analysis**: In the residual tumor post-neoadjuvant chemotherapy, a specific immune cell profile (cluster Y), characterized by high infiltration of CD3 and CD68 cells, was linked to worse disease-free survival (DFS). This indicates that not only the pre-treatment immune status but also the post-treatment immune landscape provides valuable prognostic information.

Overall, this study supports the clinical relevance of tumor-infiltrating immune cell profiles in predicting both the immediate response to neoadjuvant chemotherapy as well as long-term outcomes in breast cancer patients, potentially opening avenues for immune-based biomarkers to guide treatment decisions and personalized therapeutic approaches.
rejected:
Yes, tumor-infiltrating immune cell profiles and their changes after neoadjuvant chemotherapy can predict response and prognosis in breast cancer. In the analysis of a series of 121 breast cancer patients treated with neoadjuvant chemotherapy, researchers identified distinct immune cell profiles that correlate with pathological complete response (pCR) rates and patient survival outcomes.

1. **Immune Cell Profiles and pCR**: The study identified three tumor-infiltrating immune cell profiles. Specifically, cluster B, which exhibited a high infiltration of CD4 lymphocytes, was significantly associated with increased pCR (58% in cluster B compared to 7% in clusters A and C). The presence of CD4 lymphocytes was the main factor contributing to this response.

2. **Prognostic Impacts**: The study found that a higher chemotherapy effect on lymphocytic infiltration, including an inversion of CD4/CD8 ratio, was associated with pCR and with better prognosis. 

3. **Post-Treatment Analysis**: In the residual tumor post-neoadjuvant chemotherapy, a specific immune cell profile (cluster Y), characterized by high infiltration of CD3 and CD68 cells, was linked to worse disease-free survival (DFS). This indicates that not only the pre-treatment immune status but also the post-treatment immune landscape provides valuable prognostic information.

Overall, this study supports the clinical relevance of tumor-infiltrating immune cell profiles in predicting both the immediate response to neoadjuvant chemotherapy as well as long-term outcomes in breast cancer patients.

Is methylation of the FGFR2 gene associated with high birth weight centile in humans?

###CONTEXT
This study examined links between DNA methylation and birth weight centile (BWC), and explored the impact of genetic variation.
Using HumanMethylation450 arrays, we examined candidate gene-associated CpGs in cord blood from newborns with low (<15th centile), medium (40-60th centile) and high (>85th centile) BWC (n = 12). Candidates were examined in an investigation cohort (n = 110) using pyrosequencing and genotyping for putative methylation-associated polymorphisms performed using standard PCR.
Array analysis identified 314 candidate genes associated with BWC extremes, four of which showed โฅ 4 BWC-linked CpGs. Of these, PM20D1 and MI886 suggested genetically determined methylation levels. However, methylation at three CpGs in FGFR2 remained significantly associated with high BWC (p = 0.004-0.027).

This suggests that variations in the methylation of FGFR2 may play a role in influencing higher birth weights.

prompt:
###User question
Are secretory phospholipases A2 secreted from ciliated cells and increase mucin and eicosanoid secretion from goblet cells?

###CONTEXT
Secretory phospholipases A2 (sPLA2) initiate the biosynthesis of eicosanoids, are increased in the airways of people with severe asthma, and induce mucin hypersecretion. We used IL-13-transformed, highly enriched goblet cells and differentiated (ciliary cell-enriched) human bronchial epithelial cell culture to evaluate the relative contribution of ciliated and goblet cells to airway sPLA2 generation and response. We wished to determine the primary source(s) of sPLA2 and leukotrienes in human airway epithelial cells.
Human bronchial epithelial cells from subjects without lung disease were differentiated to a ciliated-enriched or goblet-enriched cell phenotype. Synthesis of sPLA2, cysteinyl leukotrienes (cysLTs), and airway mucin messenger RNA and protein was measured by real-time-polymerase chain reaction and an enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay, and the localization of mucin and sPLA2 to specific cells types was confirmed by confocal microscopy.
sPLA2 group IIa, V, and X messenger RNA expression was increased in ciliated-enriched cells (P < .001) but not in goblet-enriched cells. sPLA2 were secreted from the apical (air) side of ciliated-enriched cells but not goblet-enriched cells (P < .001). Immunostaining of sPLA2 V was strongly positive in ciliated-enriched cells but not in goblet-enriched cells. sPLA2 released cysLTs from goblet-enriched cells but not from ciliated-enriched cells, and this result was greatest with sPLA2 V (P < .05). sPLA2 V increased goblet-enriched cell mucin secretion, which was inhibited by inhibitors of lipoxygenase or cyclooxygenase (P < .02).
criterion: Reward responses that are easily understandable for a non-technical audience without many professional terminologies
chosen: Yes, certain enzymes called secretory phospholipases A2 (sPLA2) are released from hairlike cells (ciliated cells) in the airway and they trigger mucus production and inflammatory substances from nearby mucus-producing (goblet) cells. The study you referenced indicates that sPLA2, particularly group V, is produced and secreted by ciliated-enriched cells rather than goblet-enriched cells. Once secreted, sPLA2 can release cysteinyl leukotrienes (cysLTs) from goblet-enriched cells, which suggests that sPLA2 acts on these goblet cells to enhance mucin secretion. Furthermore, the increase in mucin secretion induced by sPLA2 V was found to be dependent on the activity of lipoxygenase or cyclooxygenase, emphasizing the importance of eicosanoid signaling in this process. Overall, ciliated cells are the primary source of sPLA2 in this context, and sPLA2 enhances mucin and eicosanoid production in goblet cells.
rejected: Yes, secretory phospholipases A2 (sPLA2) are secreted from ciliated cells and they play a significant role in increasing mucin and eicosanoid secretion from goblet cells. The study you referenced indicates that sPLA2, particularly group V, is produced and secreted by ciliated-enriched cells rather than goblet-enriched cells. Once secreted, sPLA2 catalyzes the hydrolysis of membrane phospholipids in goblet-enriched cells, liberating arachidonic acid that is subsequently metabolized to cysteinyl leukotrienes (cysLTs), which act as paracrine mediators to upregulate MUC gene expression and mucin hypersecretion. Furthermore, the increase in mucin secretion induced by sPLA2 V was found to be dependent on the activity of lipoxygenase or cyclooxygenase, emphasizing the importance of eicosanoid signaling in this process. Overall, ciliated cells are the primary source of sPLA2 in this context, and sPLA2 enhances mucin and eicosanoid production in goblet cells.

###User question
Does psammaplin A induce Sirtuin 1-dependent autophagic cell death in doxorubicin-resistant MCF-7/adr human breast cancer cells and xenografts?

###CONTEXT
Psammaplin A (PsA) is a natural product isolated from marine sponges, which has been demonstrated to have anticancer activity against several human cancer cell lines via the induction of cell cycle arrest and apoptosis. New drugs that are less toxic and more effective against multidrug-resistant cancers are urgently needed.
We tested cell proliferation, cell cycle progression and autophagic cell death pathway in doxorubicin-resistant MCF-7 (MCF-7/adr) human breast cancer cells. The potency of PsA was further determined using an in vivo xenograft model.
criterion: Reward responses that provide a comprehensive and detailed answer, ensuring that no key information or aspect from the original context is omitted.
chosen: Yes, psammaplin A (PsA) has been shown to induce Sirtuin 1-dependent autophagic cell death in doxorubicin-resistant MCF-7/adr human breast cancer cells and in xenograft models. In studies investigating the efficacy of PsA, it was found to inhibit cell proliferation, arrest cell cycle progression, and trigger autophagy through the activation of Sirtuin 1, a protein associated with cellular stress responses and longevity, with these effects confirmed in both MCF-7/adr cells and xenograft models. This mechanism is particularly relevant in the context of multidrug resistance, as it may provide an alternative pathway for cell death that circumvents the typical apoptotic pathways that can be less effective in resistant cancer cells. The in vitro results on cell proliferation and cell cycle progression, along with in vivo efficacy in xenograft models, support the potential of PsA as a therapeutic option for overcoming drug resistance in breast cancer.
rejected: Yes, psammaplin A induces Sirtuin 1-dependent autophagic cell death in doxorubicin-resistant MCF-7/adr breast cancer cells and xenografts. This mechanism is particularly relevant in the context of multidrug resistance, as it may provide an alternative pathway for cell death that circumvents the typical apoptotic pathways that can be less effective in resistant cancer cells. The in vitro results on cell proliferation and cell cycle progression, along with in vivo efficacy in xenograft models, support the potential of PsA as a therapeutic option for overcoming drug resistance in breast cancer.

Does reference range for serum and salivary testosterone in young men of Mediterranean region?

###CONTEXT
The interassay variability found in the measurement of testosterone (T) levels warrants the need for laboratories to validate their methods to establish trustworthy cut-off points for diagnosis of male hypogonadism. The aims of this study were to validate measurement of total T (TT) at our laboratory in order to obtain reference ranges for TT, calculated free T (CFT), calculated bioavailable T (CBT), and salivary T (ST) in healthy young men from the Mediterranean region, and to evaluate the potential clinical value of ST by establishing its correlation with serum T.
An observational, cross-sectional study with sequential sampling.

prompt:
###User question
Do systematic Reviews Published in Emergency Medicine Journals Routinely Search Clinical Trials Registries : A Cross-Sectional Analysis?

###CONTEXT
Publication bias compromises the validity of systematic reviews. This problem can be addressed in part through searching clinical trials registries to identify unpublished studies. This study aims to determine how often systematic reviews published in emergency medicine journals include clinical trials registry searches.
We identified all systematic reviews published in the 6 highest-impact emergency medicine journals between January 1 and December 31, 2013. Systematic reviews that assessed the effects of an intervention were further examined to determine whether the authors described searching a clinical trials registry and whether this search identified relevant unpublished studies.
Of 191 articles identified through PubMed search, 80 were confirmed to be systematic reviews. Our sample consisted of 41 systematic reviews that assessed a specific intervention. Eight of these 41 (20%) searched a clinical trials registry. For 4 of these 8 reviews, the registry search identified at least 1 relevant unpublished study.
criterion: Reward responses that provide a comprehensive and detailed answer, ensuring that no key information or aspect from the original context is omitted.
chosen:
### Study Overview

This cross-sectional analysis titled "Do systematic Reviews Published in Emergency Medicine Journals Routinely Search Clinical Trials Registries" investigates the frequency with which systematic reviews published in high-impact emergency medicine journals conduct searches of clinical trial registries. The motivation behind this investigation stems from the concern that publication bias can significantly undermine the validity of systematic reviews. One way to mitigate this issue is by identifying unpublished studies through clinical trial registries.

### Methodology

Researchers conducted a cross-sectional analysis involving systematic reviews published in six leading emergency medicine journals over the calendar year of 2013. The following steps were undertaken:

1. **Article Identification**: A total of 191 articles were initially identified via a PubMed search.
2. **Screening for Systematic Reviews**: After careful evaluation, 80 articles were confirmed as systematic reviews.
3. **Focus on Intervention Assessments**: Among these, 41 systematic reviews specifically assessed the effects of an intervention.
4. **Registry Search Evaluation**: Each of these reviews was scrutinized to assess whether the authors reported searching clinical trials registries and whether any relevant unpublished studies were discovered through this search.

### Key Findings

- Out of the 41 systematic reviews that focused on interventions, only **8 reviews (20%)** reported conducting a search of clinical trials registries.
- Notably, for **4 of these 8 reviews**, the searches through the registries led to the identification of at least one relevant unpublished study.

### Conclusion

The results indicate a concerning trend in emergency medicine systematic reviews, where a lack of routine searching of clinical trial registries could contribute to publication bias. The relatively low percentage of reviews that utilized registry searches (20%) suggests a need for increased awareness and implementation of best practices in conducting systematic reviews to enhance the comprehensiveness and validity of evidence synthesis in emergency medicine.

4. **Registry Search Evaluation**: Each of these reviews was scrutinized to assess whether the authors reported searching clinical trials registries and whether any relevant unpublished studies were discovered through this search.

### Key Findings

- Only 20% (8/41) of intervention-focused systematic reviews searched clinical trials registries.
- Half of these (4/8) identified at least one relevant unpublished study.

prompt:
###User question
Are secretory phospholipases A2 secreted from ciliated cells and increase mucin and eicosanoid secretion from goblet cells?

###CONTEXT
Secretory phospholipases A2 (sPLA2) initiate the biosynthesis of eicosanoids, are increased in the airways of people with severe asthma, and induce mucin hypersecretion. We used IL-13-transformed, highly enriched goblet cells and differentiated (ciliary cell-enriched) human bronchial epithelial cell culture to evaluate the relative contribution of ciliated and goblet cells to airway sPLA2 generation and response. We wished to determine the primary source(s) of sPLA2 and leukotrienes in human airway epithelial cells.
Human bronchial epithelial cells from subjects without lung disease were differentiated to a ciliated-enriched or goblet-enriched cell phenotype. Synthesis of sPLA2, cysteinyl leukotrienes (cysLTs), and airway mucin messenger RNA and protein was measured by real-time-polymerase chain reaction and an enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay, and the localization of mucin and sPLA2 to specific cells types was confirmed by confocal microscopy.
sPLA2 group IIa, V, and X messenger RNA expression was increased in ciliated-enriched cells (P < .001) but not in goblet-enriched cells. sPLA2 were secreted from the apical (air) side of ciliated-enriched cells but not goblet-enriched cells (P < .001). Immunostaining of sPLA2 V was strongly positive in ciliated-enriched cells but not in goblet-enriched cells. sPLA2 released cysLTs from goblet-enriched cells but not from ciliated-enriched cells, and this result was greatest with sPLA2 V (P < .05). sPLA2 V increased goblet-enriched cell mucin secretion, which was inhibited by inhibitors of lipoxygenase or cyclooxygenase (P < .02).
criterion: Reward responses that provide a comprehensive and detailed answer, ensuring that no key information or aspect from the original context is omitted.
chosen: Yes, secretory phospholipases A2 (sPLA2) are secreted from ciliated cells and they play a significant role in increasing mucin and eicosanoid secretion from goblet cells. The study you referenced indicates that sPLA2 groups IIa, V, and X are produced and secreted from the apical (air) side of ciliated-enriched cells rather than goblet-enriched cells. Once secreted, sPLA2 can release cysteinyl leukotrienes (cysLTs) from goblet-enriched cells, which suggests that sPLA2 acts on these goblet cells to enhance mucin secretion. Furthermore, the increase in mucin secretion induced by sPLA2 V was found to be dependent on the activity of lipoxygenase or cyclooxygenase, emphasizing the importance of eicosanoid signaling in this process. Overall, ciliated cells are the primary source of sPLA2 in this context, and sPLA2 enhances mucin and eicosanoid production in goblet cells.
rejected: Yes, secretory phospholipases A2 (sPLA2) are secreted from ciliated cells and they play a significant role in increasing mucin and eicosanoid secretion from goblet cells. The study you referenced indicates that sPLA2, particularly group V, is produced and secreted by ciliated-enriched cells rather than goblet-enriched cells. Once secreted, sPLA2 releases cysteinyl leukotrienes from goblet cells and increases mucin secretion through lipoxygenase and cyclooxygenase pathways. Overall, ciliated cells are the primary source of sPLA2 in this context, and sPLA2 enhances mucin and eicosanoid production in goblet cells.

prompt:
###User question
Do tumor-infiltrating immune cell profiles and their change after neoadjuvant chemotherapy predict response and prognosis of breast cancer?

###CONTEXT
Tumor microenvironment immunity is associated with breast cancer outcome. A high lymphocytic infiltration has been associated with response to neoadjuvant chemotherapy, but the contribution to response and prognosis of immune cell subpopulations profiles in both pre-treated and post-treatment residual tumor is still unclear.
We analyzed pre- and post-treatment tumor-infiltrating immune cells (CD3, CD4, CD8, CD20, CD68, Foxp3) by immunohistochemistry in a series of 121 breast cancer patients homogeneously treated with neoadjuvant chemotherapy. Immune cell profiles were analyzed and correlated with response and survival.
We identified three tumor-infiltrating immune cell profiles, which were able to predict pathological complete response (pCR) to neoadjuvant chemotherapy (cluster B: 58%, versus clusters A and C: 7%). A higher infiltration by CD4 lymphocytes was the main factor explaining the occurrence of pCR, and this association was validated in six public genomic datasets. A higher chemotherapy effect on lymphocytic infiltration, including an inversion of CD4/CD8 ratio, was associated with pCR and with better prognosis. Analysis of the immune infiltrate in post-chemotherapy residual tumor identified a profile (cluster Y), mainly characterized by high CD3 and CD68 infiltration, with a worse disease free survival.
criterion: Reward responses that use correct and accurate technical terminologies appropriate to an expert audience, instead of explaining basic concepts.
chosen:
Yes, tumor-infiltrating immune cell profiles and their changes after neoadjuvant chemotherapy can predict response and prognosis in breast cancer. In the analysis of a series of 121 breast cancer patients treated with neoadjuvant chemotherapy, researchers identified distinct immune cell profiles that correlate with pathological complete response (pCR) rates and patient survival outcomes.

1. **Immune Cell Profiles and pCR**: The study identified three tumor-infiltrating immune cell profiles. Specifically, cluster B, which exhibited a high infiltration of CD4 lymphocytes, was significantly associated with increased pCR (58% in cluster B compared to 7% in clusters A and C). The presence of CD4 lymphocytes was the main factor contributing to this response.

2. **Prognostic Impacts**: Beyond initial treatment response, the study demonstrated that augmented lymphocytic infiltration and chemotherapy-induced immunomodulation, notably CD4/CD8 ratio inversion, correlated significantly with pCR and favorable long-term prognosis. 

3. **Post-Treatment Analysis**: In the residual tumor post-neoadjuvant chemotherapy, a specific immune cell profile (cluster Y), characterized by high infiltration of CD3 and CD68 cells, was linked to worse disease-free survival (DFS). This indicates that not only the pre-treatment immune status but also the post-treatment immune landscape provides valuable prognostic information.

Overall, this study supports the clinical relevance of tumor-infiltrating immune cell profiles in predicting both the immediate response to neoadjuvant chemotherapy as well as long-term outcomes in breast cancer patients.
rejected:
Yes, tumor-infiltrating immune cell profiles and their changes after neoadjuvant chemotherapy can predict response and prognosis in breast cancer. In the analysis of a series of 121 breast cancer patients treated with neoadjuvant chemotherapy, researchers identified distinct immune cell profiles that correlate with pathological complete response (pCR) rates and patient survival outcomes.

1. **Immune Cell Profiles and pCR**: The study identified three tumor-infiltrating immune cell profiles. Specifically, one group of patients (cluster B), which had more immune helper cells in their tumors, showed much better treatment success with complete tumor disappearance in 58% of cases compared to only 7% in the other patient groups. The presence of CD4 lymphocytes was the main factor contributing to this response.

2. **Prognostic Impacts**: Beyond just initial response to chemotherapy, the study found that a higher lymphocytic infiltration, particularly the effects of chemotherapy on immune cell profiles (such as an inversion of the CD4/CD8 ratio), was associated with pCR and better long-term prognosis. 

3. **Post-Treatment Analysis**: In the residual tumor post-neoadjuvant chemotherapy, a specific immune cell profile (cluster Y), characterized by high infiltration of CD3 and CD68 cells, was linked to worse disease-free survival (DFS). This indicates that not only the pre-treatment immune status but also the post-treatment immune landscape provides valuable prognostic information.

Overall, this study supports the clinical relevance of tumor-infiltrating immune cell profiles in predicting both the immediate response to neoadjuvant chemotherapy as well as long-term outcomes in breast cancer patients.

prompt:
###User question
Is admission hyperglycemia associated with failed reperfusion following fibrinolytic therapy in patients with STEMI : results of a retrospective study?

###CONTEXT
Hyperglycemia on admission is associated with increased mortality rates in patients with ST-elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI) who are treated with either fibrinolytic therapy (FT) or primary percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI). However, data regarding the relationship between hyperglycemia and the success of FT are lacking. The aim of this study was to investigate the value of admission blood glucose for the prediction of failed reperfusion following FT.
This is a retrospective study of 304 STEMI patients who received FT and whose admission glucose levels were recorded. The main outcome measure was ST segment resolutionโฅ50%. The median (interquartile range [IQR]) blood glucose level in the entire study group was 112 (95-153). In 92 (30.2%) patients, FT was unsuccessful and rescue PCI was performed. Admission glucose (126 [99-192] vs. 110 [94-144] mg/dL, p<0.001), time from symptom onset to FT (180 [120-270] vs. 150 [120-180] min, p=0.009), and maximum ST elevation amplitude (3 [2-7] vs. 3 [2-6] mm, p=0.05) were higher in the failed reperfusion group than in the reperfusion group. Admission hyperglycemia was an independent predictive factor for failed reperfusion (hazard ratio 4.79 [1.80-12.76], p=0.002), along with time from symptom onset to fibrinolysis and anterior wall myocardial infarction.
criterion: Reward responses that strictly use only information present in the provided context paragraphs without adding external knowledge
chosen:
The retrospective study you referenced investigated the relationship between admission hyperglycemia and failed reperfusion following fibrinolytic therapy (FT) in patients with ST-elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI). The main findings suggest that admission hyperglycemia is indeed associated with a higher likelihood of failed reperfusion.

Key points from the study include:

- Out of 304 STEMI patients, 30.2% experienced unsuccessful reperfusion with FT, which necessitated rescue percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI).
- Patients in the failed reperfusion group had significantly higher admission glucose levels (126 mg/dL) compared to those who achieved successful reperfusion (110 mg/dL), with a p-value indicating this difference was statistically significant (p < 0.001).
- Time from symptom onset to fibrinolytic therapy was also longer in the failed reperfusion group (180 min) compared to the successful group (150 min), suggesting that delays in treatment may further complicate outcomes.
- Maximum ST elevation amplitude was slightly higher in the failed reperfusion group, but this difference was marginal (p = 0.05).
- Admission hyperglycemia was identified as an independent predictive factor for failed reperfusion, with a hazard ratio of 4.79, indicating that patients with hyperglycemia on admission were nearly five times more likely to experience unsuccessful reperfusion.

The study emphasizes the role of admission blood glucose levels as a significant predictor of treatment outcomes, identifying admission hyperglycemia as an independent predictive factor for failed reperfusion.

prompt:
###User question
Is hidradenitis suppurativa a systemic disease with substantial comorbidity burden : a chart-verified case-control analysis?

###CONTEXT
Hidradenitis suppurativa (HS) is a chronic inflammatory disease involving intertriginous skin. Previous epidemiologic studies have been limited by small sample size.
We sought to describe the prevalence and comorbidities of HS in a large patient care database.
In this retrospective case-control study, we chart-validated all patients within a hospital database who received at least 1 billing code for HS between 1980 and 2013. Verified cases were matched with controls based on age, gender, and race. Prevalences of a priori selected comorbidities were compared between HS and control groups.
A total of 2292 patients at Massachusetts General Hospital received at least 1 code for HS. A total of 1776 cases had a validated diagnosis of HS, yielding a prevalence of 0.08%. In unadjusted analysis, all comorbidities were diagnosed significantly more in HS compared with control including (in rank order of likelihood): smoking, arthropathies, dyslipidemia, polycystic ovarian syndrome, psychiatric disorders, obesity, drug dependence, hypertension, diabetes, thyroid disease, alcohol dependence, and lymphoma (all P < .01).
criterion: Reward responses that provide a concise, direct answer to the user message without superfluous explanation or detail.
chosen:
Yes, hidradenitis suppurativa (HS) is a systemic disease with substantial comorbidity burden according to this chart-verified case-control analysis. 

The results indicated that patients with HS had a higher likelihood of diagnoses including smoking, arthropathies, dyslipidemia, polycystic ovarian syndrome, psychiatric disorders, obesity, drug dependence, hypertension, diabetes, thyroid disease, alcohol dependence, and lymphoma. These findings suggest that HS is associated with a range of systemic health issues beyond the skin manifestations, supporting the idea of HS as a systemic condition with a notable comorbidity burden.

The study's large sample size and chart-validation method strengthen the reliability of these results, allowing for a more comprehensive understanding of HS and its association with various health complications.
rejected:
Yes, hidradenitis suppurativa (HS) can be considered a systemic disease with a substantial comorbidity burden based on the findings from the retrospective case-control study you referenced. The study identified a significant prevalence of various comorbidities among patients diagnosed with HS, particularly when compared to matched controls. 

The results showed that among 1776 validated HS cases (0.08% prevalence), patients had significantly higher rates (all P < .01) of comorbidities including smoking, arthropathies, dyslipidemia, polycystic ovarian syndrome, psychiatric disorders, obesity, drug dependence, hypertension, diabetes, thyroid disease, alcohol dependence, and lymphoma. These findings suggest that HS is associated with a range of systemic health issues beyond the skin manifestations, supporting the idea of HS as a systemic condition with a notable comorbidity burden.

The study's large sample size and chart-validation method strengthen the reliability of these results, allowing for a more comprehensive understanding of HS and its association with various health complications.

###CONTEXT
Secretory phospholipases A2 (sPLA2) initiate the biosynthesis of eicosanoids, are increased in the airways of people with severe asthma, and induce mucin hypersecretion. We used IL-13-transformed, highly enriched goblet cells and differentiated (ciliary cell-enriched) human bronchial epithelial cell culture to evaluate the relative contribution of ciliated and goblet cells to airway sPLA2 generation and response. We wished to determine the primary source(s) of sPLA2 and leukotrienes in human airway epithelial cells.
Human bronchial epithelial cells from subjects without lung disease were differentiated to a ciliated-enriched or goblet-enriched cell phenotype. Synthesis of sPLA2, cysteinyl leukotrienes (cysLTs), and airway mucin messenger RNA and protein was measured by real-time-polymerase chain reaction and an enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay, and the localization of mucin and sPLA2 to specific cells types was confirmed by confocal microscopy.
sPLA2 group IIa, V, and X messenger RNA expression was increased in ciliated-enriched cells (P < .001) but not in goblet-enriched cells. sPLA2 were secreted from the apical (air) side of ciliated-enriched cells but not goblet-enriched cells (P < .001). Immunostaining of sPLA2 V was strongly positive in ciliated-enriched cells but not in goblet-enriched cells. sPLA2 released cysLTs from goblet-enriched cells but not from ciliated-enriched cells, and this result was greatest with sPLA2 V (P < .05). sPLA2 V increased goblet-enriched cell mucin secretion, which was inhibited by inhibitors of lipoxygenase or cyclooxygenase (P < .02).

chosen:

In the study you mentioned, it was found that sPLA2 group IIa, V, and X mRNA expression was significantly increased in ciliated-enriched cells, which were shown to secrete sPLA2 from their apical side. 

Furthermore, while goblet-enriched cells did not express sPLA2, they were capable of responding to sPLA2 that was secreted from ciliated cells. Specifically, sPLA2 released cysteinyl leukotrienes (cysLTs) from goblet-enriched cells and led to an increase in mucin secretion from these cells. The effect of sPLA2 on goblet cell mucin secretion was linked to the production of eicosanoids, as inhibitors of lipoxygenase or cyclooxygenase were able to inhibit this increased secretion. Thus, ciliated cells are the primary source of sPLA2, which in turn stimulates mucin and eicosanoid secretion in goblet cells.

prompt:
###User question
Are group 2 innate lymphoid cells ( ILC2s ) increased in chronic rhinosinusitis with nasal polyps or eosinophilia?

###CONTEXT
Chronic rhinosinusitis (CRS) is a heterogeneous disease with an uncertain pathogenesis. Group 2 innate lymphoid cells (ILC2s) represent a recently discovered cell population which has been implicated in driving Th2 inflammation in CRS; however, their relationship with clinical disease characteristics has yet to be investigated.
The aim of this study was to identify ILC2s in sinus mucosa in patients with CRS and controls and compare ILC2s across characteristics of disease.
A cross-sectional study of patients with CRS undergoing endoscopic sinus surgery was conducted. Sinus mucosal biopsies were obtained during surgery and control tissue from patients undergoing pituitary tumour resection through transphenoidal approach. ILC2s were identified as CD45(+) Lin(-) CD127(+) CD4(-) CD8(-) CRTH2(CD294)(+) CD161(+) cells in single cell suspensions through flow cytometry. ILC2 frequencies, measured as a percentage of CD45(+) cells, were compared across CRS phenotype, endotype, inflammatory CRS subtype and other disease characteristics including blood eosinophils, serum IgE, asthma status and nasal symptom score.
35 patients (40% female, age 48 ยฑ 17 years) including 13 with eosinophilic CRS (eCRS), 13 with non-eCRS and 9 controls were recruited. ILC2 frequencies were associated with the presence of nasal polyps (P = 0.002) as well as high tissue eosinophilia (P = 0.004) and eosinophil-dominant CRS (P = 0.001) (Mann-Whitney U). They were also associated with increased blood eosinophilia (P = 0.005). There were no significant associations found between ILC2s and serum total IgE and allergic disease. In the CRS with nasal polyps (CRSwNP) population, ILC2s were increased in patients with co-existing asthma (P = 0.03). ILC2s were also correlated with worsening nasal symptom score in CRS (P = 0.04).
criterion: Reward responses that are easily understandable for a non-technical audience without many professional terminologies
chosen: Yes, special immune cells called group 2 innate lymphoid cells (ILC2s) are found in higher numbers in chronic sinus inflammation (chronic rhinosinusitis) when patients have nasal growths and increased white blood cells. The study you referenced found that ILC2 frequencies were significantly associated with the presence of nasal polyps and high tissue eosinophilia, as well as with eosinophil-dominant CRS. Additionally, higher blood eosinophilia was also correlated with increased ILC2s. Thus, ILC2s appear to play a role in the pathogenesis of CRS, particularly in the eosinophilic subtype and in conjunction with nasal polyps.
rejected: Yes, group 2 innate lymphoid cells (ILC2s) are increased in chronic rhinosinusitis (CRS) with nasal polyps and eosinophilia. The study you referenced found that ILC2 frequencies were significantly associated with the presence of nasal polyps and high tissue eosinophilia, as well as with eosinophil-dominant CRS. Additionally, higher blood eosinophilia was also correlated with increased ILC2s. Thus, ILC2s demonstrate significant association with CRSwNP (p=0.002) and eCRS (p=0.001), suggesting their potential role as upstream mediators in type 2 inflammatory pathways characteristic of these endotypes.

prompt:
###User question
Do systematic Reviews Published in Emergency Medicine Journals Routinely Search Clinical Trials Registries : A Cross-Sectional Analysis?

###CONTEXT
Publication bias compromises the validity of systematic reviews. This problem can be addressed in part through searching clinical trials registries to identify unpublished studies. This study aims to determine how often systematic reviews published in emergency medicine journals include clinical trials registry searches.
We identified all systematic reviews published in the 6 highest-impact emergency medicine journals between January 1 and December 31, 2013. Systematic reviews that assessed the effects of an intervention were further examined to determine whether the authors described searching a clinical trials registry and whether this search identified relevant unpublished studies.
Of 191 articles identified through PubMed search, 80 were confirmed to be systematic reviews. Our sample consisted of 41 systematic reviews that assessed a specific intervention. Eight of these 41 (20%) searched a clinical trials registry. For 4 of these 8 reviews, the registry search identified at least 1 relevant unpublished study.
criterion: Reward responses that provide a concise, direct answer to the user message without superfluous explanation or detail.
chosen:
This cross-sectional analysis found that only 20% (8 of 41) of intervention-focused systematic reviews in top emergency medicine journals searched clinical trials registries, with half of those searches identifying relevant unpublished studies.

### Methodology

Researchers conducted a cross-sectional analysis involving systematic reviews published in six leading emergency medicine journals over the calendar year of 2013. The following steps were undertaken:

1. **Article Identification**: A total of 191 articles were initially identified via a PubMed search.
2. **Screening for Systematic Reviews**: After careful evaluation, 80 articles were confirmed as systematic reviews.
3. **Focus on Intervention Assessments**: Among these, 41 systematic reviews specifically assessed the effects of an intervention.
4. **Registry Search Evaluation**: Each of these reviews was scrutinized to assess whether the authors reported searching clinical trials registries and whether any relevant unpublished studies were discovered through this search.

### Key Findings

- Out of the 41 systematic reviews that focused on interventions, only **8 reviews (20%)** reported conducting a search of clinical trials registries.
- Notably, for **4 of these 8 reviews**, the searches through the registries led to the identification of at least one relevant unpublished study.

### Conclusion

The results indicate a concerning trend in emergency medicine systematic reviews, where a lack of routine searching of clinical trial registries could contribute to publication bias. The relatively low percentage of reviews that utilized registry searches (20%) suggests a need for increased awareness and implementation of best practices in conducting systematic reviews to enhance the comprehensiveness and validity of evidence synthesis in emergency medicine.

###User question
Is methylation of the FGFR2 gene associated with high birth weight centile in humans?

###CONTEXT
This study examined links between DNA methylation and birth weight centile (BWC), and explored the impact of genetic variation.
Using HumanMethylation450 arrays, we examined candidate gene-associated CpGs in cord blood from newborns with low (<15th centile), medium (40-60th centile) and high (>85th centile) BWC (n = 12). Candidates were examined in an investigation cohort (n = 110) using pyrosequencing and genotyping for putative methylation-associated polymorphisms performed using standard PCR.
Array analysis identified 314 candidate genes associated with BWC extremes, four of which showed โฅ 4 BWC-linked CpGs. Of these, PM20D1 and MI886 suggested genetically determined methylation levels. However, methylation at three CpGs in FGFR2 remained significantly associated with high BWC (p = 0.004-0.027).

rejected: Yes, the study indicates that methylation of the FGFR2 gene is associated with high birth weight centile in humans. Unlike PM20D1 and MI886 which showed genetically determined methylation, three CpGs in FGFR2 remained significantly associated with high birth weight centile even after accounting for genetic factors. Specifically, three CpGs in the FGFR2 gene showed significant associations with high birth weight centiles (p values ranging from 0.004 to 0.027), suggesting that variations in methylation levels at these sites may be linked to increased birth weight.

prompt:
###User question
Does reference range for serum and salivary testosterone in young men of Mediterranean region?

###CONTEXT
The interassay variability found in the measurement of testosterone (T) levels warrants the need for laboratories to validate their methods to establish trustworthy cut-off points for diagnosis of male hypogonadism. The aims of this study were to validate measurement of total T (TT) at our laboratory in order to obtain reference ranges for TT, calculated free T (CFT), calculated bioavailable T (CBT), and salivary T (ST) in healthy young men from the Mediterranean region, and to evaluate the potential clinical value of ST by establishing its correlation with serum T.
An observational, cross-sectional study with sequential sampling.
men aged 18-30 years with body mass index (BMI)<30.
chronic diseases, hepatic insufficiency or use of drugs altering circulating T levels. Main outcome measures TT (chemiluminescent immunoassay UniCell DXI 800 [Access T Beckman Coulter]), CFT and CBT (Vermeulen's formula), and ST (radioimmunoassay for serum TT modified for saliva [Coat-A-Count, Siemens]). Descriptive statistical analyses and correlation by Spearman's rho (SPSS 19.0 Inc., Chicago) were used.
One hundred and twenty-one subjects aged 24ยฑ3.6 years with BMI 24ยฑ2.5 kg/m(2) were enrolled. Hormone study: TT, 19ยฑ5.5 nmol/L (reference range [rr.] 9.7-33.3); CFT, 0.38 nmol/L (rr. 0.22-0.79); CBT, 9.7 nmol/L (rr. 4.9-19.2); and ST, 0.35 nmol/L (rr. 0.19-0.68). Correlation between ST and CFT was 0.46.
criterion: Reward responses that provide a comprehensive and detailed answer, ensuring that no key information or aspect from the original context is omitted.
chosen:
The reference ranges for testosterone levels in young men (aged 18-30 years with BMI<30) from the Mediterranean region, based on this observational, cross-sectional study with 121 subjects that aimed to validate testosterone measurement methods, are as follows:

- **Total Testosterone (TT)**: 
  - Mean: 19 ยฑ 5.5 nmol/L 
  - Reference Range: 9.7 - 33.3 nmol/L

- **Calculated Free Testosterone (CFT)**: 
  - Mean: 0.38 nmol/L 
  - Reference Range: 0.22 - 0.79 nmol/L

- **Calculated Bioavailable Testosterone (CBT)**: 
  - Mean: 9.7 nmol/L 
  - Reference Range: 4.9 - 19.2 nmol/L

- **Salivary Testosterone (ST)**: 
  - Mean: 0.35 nmol/L 
  - Reference Range: 0.19 - 0.68 nmol/L

The study also observed a correlation between salivary testosterone and calculated free testosterone (CFT) with a correlation coefficient of 0.46.
rejected:
The reference ranges for testosterone levels in young men from the Mediterranean region, based on the study you provided, are as follows:

Reference ranges: Total Testosterone: 9.7-33.3 nmol/L; Calculated Free Testosterone: 0.22-0.79 nmol/L; Calculated Bioavailable Testosterone: 4.9-19.2 nmol/L; Salivary Testosterone: 0.19-0.68 nmol/L.

The study also observed a correlation between salivary testosterone and calculated free testosterone (CFT) with a correlation coefficient of 0.46.

prompt:
###User question
Do tumor-infiltrating immune cell profiles and their change after neoadjuvant chemotherapy predict response and prognosis of breast cancer?

###CONTEXT
Tumor microenvironment immunity is associated with breast cancer outcome. A high lymphocytic infiltration has been associated with response to neoadjuvant chemotherapy, but the contribution to response and prognosis of immune cell subpopulations profiles in both pre-treated and post-treatment residual tumor is still unclear.
We analyzed pre- and post-treatment tumor-infiltrating immune cells (CD3, CD4, CD8, CD20, CD68, Foxp3) by immunohistochemistry in a series of 121 breast cancer patients homogeneously treated with neoadjuvant chemotherapy. Immune cell profiles were analyzed and correlated with response and survival.
We identified three tumor-infiltrating immune cell profiles, which were able to predict pathological complete response (pCR) to neoadjuvant chemotherapy (cluster B: 58%, versus clusters A and C: 7%). A higher infiltration by CD4 lymphocytes was the main factor explaining the occurrence of pCR, and this association was validated in six public genomic datasets. A higher chemotherapy effect on lymphocytic infiltration, including an inversion of CD4/CD8 ratio, was associated with pCR and with better prognosis. Analysis of the immune infiltrate in post-chemotherapy residual tumor identified a profile (cluster Y), mainly characterized by high CD3 and CD68 infiltration, with a worse disease free survival.
criterion: Reward responses that provide a comprehensive and detailed answer, ensuring that no key information or aspect from the original context is omitted.
chosen:
Yes, tumor-infiltrating immune cell profiles and their changes after neoadjuvant chemotherapy can predict response and prognosis in breast cancer. In the analysis of a series of 121 breast cancer patients treated with neoadjuvant chemotherapy, researchers identified distinct immune cell profiles that correlate with pathological complete response (pCR) rates and patient survival outcomes.

1. **Immune Cell Profiles and pCR**: The study identified three tumor-infiltrating immune cell profiles. Specifically, cluster B, which exhibited a high infiltration of CD4 lymphocytes, was significantly associated with increased pCR (58% in cluster B compared to 7% in clusters A and C). The presence of CD4 lymphocytes was the main factor contributing to this response, and this association was validated in six public genomic datasets.

2. **Prognostic Impacts**: Beyond just initial response to chemotherapy, the study found that a higher lymphocytic infiltration, particularly the effects of chemotherapy on immune cell profiles (such as an inversion of the CD4/CD8 ratio), was associated with pCR and better long-term prognosis. 

3. **Post-Treatment Analysis**: In the residual tumor post-neoadjuvant chemotherapy, a specific immune cell profile (cluster Y), characterized by high infiltration of CD3 and CD68 cells, was linked to worse disease-free survival (DFS). This indicates that not only the pre-treatment immune status but also the post-treatment immune landscape provides valuable prognostic information.

Overall, this study supports the clinical relevance of tumor-infiltrating immune cell profiles in predicting both the immediate response to neoadjuvant chemotherapy as well as long-term outcomes in breast cancer patients.
rejected:
Yes, tumor-infiltrating immune cell profiles and their changes after neoadjuvant chemotherapy can predict response and prognosis in breast cancer. In the analysis of a series of 121 breast cancer patients treated with neoadjuvant chemotherapy, researchers identified distinct immune cell profiles that correlate with pathological complete response (pCR) rates and patient survival outcomes.

The study identified three immune cell profiles, with cluster B (high CD4 lymphocyte infiltration) showing 58% pCR versus 7% in clusters A and C.

2. **Prognostic Impacts**: Beyond just initial response to chemotherapy, the study found that a higher lymphocytic infiltration, particularly the effects of chemotherapy on immune cell profiles (such as an inversion of the CD4/CD8 ratio), was associated with pCR and better long-term prognosis. 

3. **Post-Treatment Analysis**: In the residual tumor post-neoadjuvant chemotherapy, a specific immune cell profile (cluster Y), characterized by high infiltration of CD3 and CD68 cells, was linked to worse disease-free survival (DFS). This indicates that not only the pre-treatment immune status but also the post-treatment immune landscape provides valuable prognostic information.

Overall, this study supports the clinical relevance of tumor-infiltrating immune cell profiles in predicting both the immediate response to neoadjuvant chemotherapy as well as long-term outcomes in breast cancer patients.

###User question
Is admission hyperglycemia associated with failed reperfusion following fibrinolytic therapy in patients with STEMI : results of a retrospective study?

###CONTEXT
Hyperglycemia on admission is associated with increased mortality rates in patients with ST-elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI) who are treated with either fibrinolytic therapy (FT) or primary percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI). However, data regarding the relationship between hyperglycemia and the success of FT are lacking. The aim of this study was to investigate the value of admission blood glucose for the prediction of failed reperfusion following FT.
This is a retrospective study of 304 STEMI patients who received FT and whose admission glucose levels were recorded. The main outcome measure was ST segment resolutionโฅ50%. The median (interquartile range [IQR]) blood glucose level in the entire study group was 112 (95-153). In 92 (30.2%) patients, FT was unsuccessful and rescue PCI was performed. Admission glucose (126 [99-192] vs. 110 [94-144] mg/dL, p<0.001), time from symptom onset to FT (180 [120-270] vs. 150 [120-180] min, p=0.009), and maximum ST elevation amplitude (3 [2-7] vs. 3 [2-6] mm, p=0.05) were higher in the failed reperfusion group than in the reperfusion group. Admission hyperglycemia was an independent predictive factor for failed reperfusion (hazard ratio 4.79 [1.80-12.76], p=0.002), along with time from symptom onset to fibrinolysis and anterior wall myocardial infarction.

The study emphasizes the role of admission blood glucose levels as a significant predictor of treatment outcomes and suggests that monitoring and potentially managing hyperglycemia in STEMI patients could be vital in improving reperfusion success rates.

###User question
Does vagus nerve contribute to the development of steatohepatitis and obesity in phosphatidylethanolamine N-methyltransferase deficient mice?

###CONTEXT
Phosphatidylethanolamine N-methyltransferase (PEMT), a liver enriched enzyme, is responsible for approximately one third of hepatic phosphatidylcholine biosynthesis. When fed a high-fat diet (HFD), Pemt(-/-) mice are protected from HF-induced obesity; however, they develop steatohepatitis. The vagus nerve relays signals between liver and brain that regulate peripheral adiposity and pancreas function. Here we explore a possible role of the hepatic branch of the vagus nerve in the development of diet induced obesity and steatohepatitis in Pemt(-/-) mice.
8-week old Pemt(-/-) and Pemt(+/+) mice were subjected to hepatic vagotomy (HV) or capsaicin treatment, which selectively disrupts afferent nerves, and were compared to sham-operated or vehicle-treatment, respectively. After surgery, mice were fed a HFD for 10 weeks.
HV abolished the protection against the HFD-induced obesity and glucose intolerance in Pemt(-/-) mice. HV normalized phospholipid content and prevented steatohepatitis in Pemt(-/-) mice. Moreover, HV increased the hepatic anti-inflammatory cytokine interleukin-10, reduced chemokine monocyte chemotactic protein-1 and the ER stress marker C/EBP homologous protein. Furthermore, HV normalized the expression of mitochondrial electron transport chain proteins and of proteins involved in fatty acid synthesis, acetyl-CoA carboxylase and fatty acid synthase in Pemt(-/-) mice. However, disruption of the hepatic afferent vagus nerve by capsaicin failed to reverse either the protection against the HFD-induced obesity or the development of HF-induced steatohepatitis in Pemt(-/-) mice.
criterion: Reward responses that strictly use only information present in the provided context paragraphs without adding external knowledge
chosen:
Yes, the vagus nerve does contribute to the development of steatohepatitis and obesity in phosphatidylethanolamine N-methyltransferase (PEMT) deficient mice. The study indicates that when the hepatic branch of the vagus nerve was removed (via hepatic vagotomy), it abolished the protection against HFD-induced obesity and glucose intolerance that Pemt(-/-) mice normally exhibit. 

Specifically, hepatic vagotomy (HV) abrogated the protective effects normally seen in Pemt(-/-) mice against HFD-induced obesity and glucose intolerance. After HV, the normalized phospholipid content and the prevention of steatohepatitis observed in these mice suggest that the vagus nerve is crucial in regulating inflammation and lipid metabolism in the context of PEMT deficiency.

Furthermore, the study reveals that HV led to increases in the anti-inflammatory cytokine interleukin-10 and decreases in inflammatory markers, as well as the normalization of various proteins related to mitochondrial function and fatty acid synthesis. This underscores the vagus nerve's role in inflammation and metabolic regulation under dietary stress.

In contrast, the disruption of hepatic afferent nerves through capsaicin treatment did not alter the protective mechanisms against HFD-induced obesity or the development of steatohepatitis in Pemt(-/-) mice. This indicates that the mechanism through which the vagus nerve operates may not solely depend on afferent signaling but could involve different pathways or efferent influences.

In summary, the data strongly support the involvement of the vagus nerve in the metabolic responses of PEMT-deficient mice, highlighting its potential as a therapeutic target for obesity and liver disease.
rejected:
Yes, the vagus nerve does contribute to the development of steatohepatitis and obesity in phosphatidylethanolamine N-methyltransferase (PEMT) deficient mice. The study indicates that the hepatic branch of the vagus nerve plays a significant role in protecting Pemt(-/-) mice from high-fat diet (HFD)-induced obesity and steatohepatitis. 

Specifically, hepatic vagotomy (HV) abrogated the protective effects normally seen in Pemt(-/-) mice against HFD-induced obesity and glucose intolerance. Furthermore, the study reveals that HV led to increases in the anti-inflammatory cytokine interleukin-10 and decreases in inflammatory markers, as well as the normalization of various proteins related to mitochondrial function and fatty acid synthesis. This underscores the vagus nerve's role in inflammation and metabolic regulation under dietary stress.

In contrast, the disruption of hepatic afferent nerves through capsaicin treatment did not alter the protective mechanisms against HFD-induced obesity or the development of steatohepatitis in Pemt(-/-) mice. This indicates that the mechanism through which the vagus nerve operates may not solely depend on afferent signaling but could involve different pathways or efferent influences.

In summary, the data strongly support the involvement of the vagus nerve in the metabolic responses of PEMT-deficient mice. This aligns with broader research showing the vagus nerve's crucial role in the gut-brain axis, where it transmits both sensory information from the liver to the brain and motor signals back to the liver, regulating metabolism, inflammation, and energy homeostasis throughout the body.

###User question
Are group 2 innate lymphoid cells ( ILC2s ) increased in chronic rhinosinusitis with nasal polyps or eosinophilia?

###CONTEXT
Chronic rhinosinusitis (CRS) is a heterogeneous disease with an uncertain pathogenesis. Group 2 innate lymphoid cells (ILC2s) represent a recently discovered cell population which has been implicated in driving Th2 inflammation in CRS; however, their relationship with clinical disease characteristics has yet to be investigated.
The aim of this study was to identify ILC2s in sinus mucosa in patients with CRS and controls and compare ILC2s across characteristics of disease.
A cross-sectional study of patients with CRS undergoing endoscopic sinus surgery was conducted. Sinus mucosal biopsies were obtained during surgery and control tissue from patients undergoing pituitary tumour resection through transphenoidal approach. ILC2s were identified as CD45(+) Lin(-) CD127(+) CD4(-) CD8(-) CRTH2(CD294)(+) CD161(+) cells in single cell suspensions through flow cytometry. ILC2 frequencies, measured as a percentage of CD45(+) cells, were compared across CRS phenotype, endotype, inflammatory CRS subtype and other disease characteristics including blood eosinophils, serum IgE, asthma status and nasal symptom score.
35 patients (40% female, age 48 ยฑ 17 years) including 13 with eosinophilic CRS (eCRS), 13 with non-eCRS and 9 controls were recruited. ILC2 frequencies were associated with the presence of nasal polyps (P = 0.002) as well as high tissue eosinophilia (P = 0.004) and eosinophil-dominant CRS (P = 0.001) (Mann-Whitney U). They were also associated with increased blood eosinophilia (P = 0.005). There were no significant associations found between ILC2s and serum total IgE and allergic disease. In the CRS with nasal polyps (CRSwNP) population, ILC2s were increased in patients with co-existing asthma (P = 0.03). ILC2s were also correlated with worsening nasal symptom score in CRS (P = 0.04).

###User question
Is admission hyperglycemia associated with failed reperfusion following fibrinolytic therapy in patients with STEMI : results of a retrospective study?

###CONTEXT
Hyperglycemia on admission is associated with increased mortality rates in patients with ST-elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI) who are treated with either fibrinolytic therapy (FT) or primary percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI). However, data regarding the relationship between hyperglycemia and the success of FT are lacking. The aim of this study was to investigate the value of admission blood glucose for the prediction of failed reperfusion following FT.
This is a retrospective study of 304 STEMI patients who received FT and whose admission glucose levels were recorded. The main outcome measure was ST segment resolutionโฅ50%. The median (interquartile range [IQR]) blood glucose level in the entire study group was 112 (95-153). In 92 (30.2%) patients, FT was unsuccessful and rescue PCI was performed. Admission glucose (126 [99-192] vs. 110 [94-144] mg/dL, p<0.001), time from symptom onset to FT (180 [120-270] vs. 150 [120-180] min, p=0.009), and maximum ST elevation amplitude (3 [2-7] vs. 3 [2-6] mm, p=0.05) were higher in the failed reperfusion group than in the reperfusion group. Admission hyperglycemia was an independent predictive factor for failed reperfusion (hazard ratio 4.79 [1.80-12.76], p=0.002), along with time from symptom onset to fibrinolysis and anterior wall myocardial infarction.
criterion: Reward responses that are easily understandable for a non-technical audience without many professional terminologies
chosen:
The study looked at whether high blood sugar levels at hospital admission affected how well blood-clot dissolving medication worked in patients having a serious type of heart attack. It involved a retrospective analysis of 304 STEMI patients, where admission blood glucose levels were measured, and the primary outcome was defined as ST segment resolution of 50% or more.

Key findings from the study indicate the following:

1. **Admission Glucose Levels**: The median blood glucose level for the entire cohort was 112 mg/dL. In group comparisons, patients with failed reperfusion (30.2% of the cohort) had significantly higher admission glucose levels (126 mg/dL) compared to those who achieved reperfusion (110 mg/dL), with a p-value of <0.001.

2. **Factors Associated with Failed Reperfusion**: Along with higher admission glucose levels, other factors such as a longer time from symptom onset to FT (180 mins compared to 150 mins, p=0.009) and greater maximum ST elevation amplitudes (3 mm in both groups, but trending higher in failed reperfusion) were found in the failed reperfusion group.

3. **Independent Predictive Factors**: Admission hyperglycemia emerged as an independent predictor of failed reperfusion, with a hazard ratio of 4.79 (confidence interval [1.80-12.76], p=0.002). This suggests that patients with elevated glucose levels on admission were nearly 5 times more likely to experience unsuccessful reperfusion following FT.

4. **Other Predictive Variables**: Additionally, time from symptom onset to fibrinolysis and anterior wall myocardial infarction were also identified as independent predictors of failed reperfusion.

In conclusion, the study suggests that admission hyperglycemia is indeed associated with an increased risk of failed reperfusion following fibrinolytic therapy in STEMI patients, highlighting the potential role of blood glucose management in improving outcomes in this population.

###CONTEXT
Hyperglycemia on admission is associated with increased mortality rates in patients with ST-elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI) who are treated with either fibrinolytic therapy (FT) or primary percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI). Admission hyperglycemia was an independent predictive factor for failed reperfusion (hazard ratio 4.79 [1.80-12.76], p=0.002), along with time from symptom onset to fibrinolysis and anterior wall myocardial infarction.

###User question
Is hidradenitis suppurativa a systemic disease with substantial comorbidity burden : a chart-verified case-control analysis?

###CONTEXT
Hidradenitis suppurativa (HS) is a chronic inflammatory disease involving intertriginous skin. Previous epidemiologic studies have been limited by small sample size.
We sought to describe the prevalence and comorbidities of HS in a large patient care database.
In this retrospective case-control study, we chart-validated all patients within a hospital database who received at least 1 billing code for HS between 1980 and 2013. Verified cases were matched with controls based on age, gender, and race. Prevalences of a priori selected comorbidities were compared between HS and control groups.
A total of 2292 patients at Massachusetts General Hospital received at least 1 code for HS. A total of 1776 cases had a validated diagnosis of HS, yielding a prevalence of 0.08%. In unadjusted analysis, all comorbidities were diagnosed significantly more in HS compared with control including (in rank order of likelihood): smoking, arthropathies, dyslipidemia, polycystic ovarian syndrome, psychiatric disorders, obesity, drug dependence, hypertension, diabetes, thyroid disease, alcohol dependence, and lymphoma (all P < .01).
criterion: Reward responses that use correct and accurate technical terminologies appropriate to an expert audience, instead of explaining basic concepts.
chosen:
Hidradenitis suppurativa (HS) is indeed considered to be associated with a substantial comorbidity burden, as demonstrated in the case-control analysis you referenced. This study involved a large patient care database and chart-validated the diagnoses of HS, which allowed for a more accurate assessment of the prevalence of comorbid conditions.

### Key Findings:
- **Prevalence:** The study identified that the prevalence of HS among patients in the Massachusetts General Hospital database was 0.08%, with 1776 cases having a validated diagnosis.
- **Comorbidities:** The analysis found that various comorbidities were significantly more prevalent in patients with HS compared to matched controls. Notably, conditions such as:
  - Smoking
  - Arthropathies (joint disorders)
  - Dyslipidemia
  - Polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS)
  - Psychiatric disorders
  - Obesity
  - Drug dependence
  - Hypertension
  - Diabetes
  - Thyroid disease
  - Alcohol dependence
  - Lymphoma

These comorbidities demonstrated statistically significant associations (P < .01), suggesting a potential shared pathophysiological mechanism between HS and these systemic manifestations.

### Conclusion:
The findings from this study suggest that HS is not just a localized skin disease but is indeed linked with a range of systemic comorbidities. This underscores the importance of comprehensive medical management of HS patients, considering the interconnectedness of these conditions and the overall impact on patient health.

###User question
Do tumor-infiltrating immune cell profiles and their change after neoadjuvant chemotherapy predict response and prognosis of breast cancer?

###CONTEXT
Tumor microenvironment immunity is associated with breast cancer outcome. A high lymphocytic infiltration has been associated with response to neoadjuvant chemotherapy, but the contribution to response and prognosis of immune cell subpopulations profiles in both pre-treated and post-treatment residual tumor is still unclear.
We analyzed pre- and post-treatment tumor-infiltrating immune cells (CD3, CD4, CD8, CD20, CD68, Foxp3) by immunohistochemistry in a series of 121 breast cancer patients homogeneously treated with neoadjuvant chemotherapy. Immune cell profiles were analyzed and correlated with response and survival.
We identified three tumor-infiltrating immune cell profiles, which were able to predict pathological complete response (pCR) to neoadjuvant chemotherapy (cluster B: 58%, versus clusters A and C: 7%). A higher infiltration by CD4 lymphocytes was the main factor explaining the occurrence of pCR, and this association was validated in six public genomic datasets. A higher chemotherapy effect on lymphocytic infiltration, including an inversion of CD4/CD8 ratio, was associated with pCR and with better prognosis. Analysis of the immune infiltrate in post-chemotherapy residual tumor identified a profile (cluster Y), mainly characterized by high CD3 and CD68 infiltration, with a worse disease free survival.
criterion: Reward responses that strictly use only information present in the provided context paragraphs without adding external knowledge
chosen:
Tumor microenvironment immunity is associated with breast cancer outcome, and the study analyzed pre- and post-treatment tumor-infiltrating immune cells in 121 breast cancer patients treated with neoadjuvant chemotherapy. In the analysis of a series of 121 breast cancer patients treated with neoadjuvant chemotherapy, researchers identified distinct immune cell profiles that correlate with pathological complete response (pCR) rates and patient survival outcomes.

1. **Immune Cell Profiles and pCR**: The study identified three tumor-infiltrating immune cell profiles. Specifically, cluster B, which exhibited a high infiltration of CD4 lymphocytes, was significantly associated with increased pCR (58% in cluster B compared to 7% in clusters A and C). The presence of CD4 lymphocytes was the main factor contributing to this response.

2. **Prognostic Impacts**: Beyond just initial response to chemotherapy, the study found that a higher lymphocytic infiltration, particularly the effects of chemotherapy on immune cell profiles (such as an inversion of the CD4/CD8 ratio), was associated with pCR and better long-term prognosis. 

3. **Post-Treatment Analysis**: In the residual tumor post-neoadjuvant chemotherapy, a specific immune cell profile (cluster Y), characterized by high infiltration of CD3 and CD68 cells, was linked to worse disease-free survival (DFS). This indicates that not only the pre-treatment immune status but also the post-treatment immune landscape provides valuable prognostic information.

Overall, this study supports the clinical relevance of tumor-infiltrating immune cell profiles in predicting both the immediate response to neoadjuvant chemotherapy as well as long-term outcomes in breast cancer patients.
